user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#if defined(HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY) && defined(HAVE_GETPID)
  /* Glibc style */
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    cpu_set_t cur_set;
    if (0 == sched_getaffinity (getpid (), sizeof (cur_set), &cur_set))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_CPU_COUNT
      ret = CPU_COUNT (&cur_set);
#else  /* ! HAVE_CPU_COUNT */
      unsigned int i;
      ret = 0;
      for (i = 0; i < CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE; ++i)
      {
        if (CPU_ISSET (i, &cur_set))
          ++ret;
      }
      if (0 == ret)
        ret = -1;
#endif /* ! HAVE_CPU_COUNT */
    }
  }
#ifdef HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* Use 256 times larger size than size for default maximum CPU number.
       Hopefully it would be enough even for exotic situations. */
    static const unsigned int set_size_cpus = 256 * CPU_SETSIZE;
    const size_t set_size_bytes = CPU_ALLOC_SIZE (set_size_cpus);
    cpu_set_t *p_set;

    p_set = CPU_ALLOC (set_size_cpus);
    if (NULL != p_set)
    {
      if (0 == sched_getaffinity (getpid (), set_size_bytes, p_set))
      {
#ifndef MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS
        ret = CPU_COUNT_S (set_size_bytes, p_set);
#else  /* MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS */
        ret = CPU_COUNT_S (set_size_cpus, p_set);
#endif /* MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS */
      }
      CPU_FREE (p_set);
    }
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S */
#endif /* HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY && HAVE_GETPID */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameters exist in mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_(void), therefore there are no parameter variables that can be modified and no direct opportunities to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. All pointer arguments passed to other functions (e.g., &cur_set, p_set) refer to local objects, not parameters of this function; modifying the objects pointed to is permitted by the rule. Assignments to local variables (e.g., p_set = CPU_ALLOC(...), ret = ...) are not violations of Rule 17.8. Calls to functions that take pointer parameters (sched_getaffinity, CPU_COUNT_S, CPU_FREE, etc.) may modify the objects they point to but do not modify any function parameter of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_. Therefore, no fragments need investigation for Rule 17.8.
